newsitem.title: EGYPT: Israeli attitude not inspiring optimism, Egypt.
newsitem.headline: Israeli attitude not inspiring optimism, Egypt.

text.p: Egypt said on Thursday that Israel's attitude at the Middle East crisis summit in Washington had not inspired optimism for the peace process.
The summit, called by U.S. President Bill Clinton after Israeli-Palestinian clashes in which 73 died, agreed only to continue negotiations between the two sides.
"The existence of good will push the negotiations forward," Foreign Minister Amr Moussa told reporters at Cairo airport at his return from U.N. general assembly meetings in New York.
"But the Israeli attitude in Washington has not inspired optimism and reassurance for the negotiations' framework and future, and consequently for the future of the peace process," he added.
Arabs dismissed the Washington summit, boycotted by Egyptian President Hosni Mubarak, as a failure for peace and a victory for Israeli intransigence.
"President Clinton exerted big efforts to contain the Israeli negative attitude," Moussa told reporters.
"But the result, as is known, was that the gathering could not bring the Israeli policy back to a path compatible with peace and its requirements."
"The (Israeli-Palestinian) negotiations cannot go on forever," he added. "All must... understand that they are not for wasting time, but to get the Palestinian track back to its right path."
Moussa said that the only way to get out of the current crisis is by the implementation of all agreements.

"This will not happen until the agreed-upon accords are fulfilled, built upon and good will shown," he said, adding in clear refernce to Israel, "This, we supposedly wait for, but we are not expecting."
Moussa said Palestinian President Yasser Arafat will visit Egypt on Saturday at the invitation of Mubarak to continue their discussions over the latest developments in the region.
